"784766", "cf_release_notes": "Cause:\r\nWhen SystemTap probes were introduced into Ruby (rhbz#673162), there was added also module Tracer with .fire method. Unfortunately, this module collides with Ruby's own Tracer class.\r\n\r\nConsequence:\r\nWhen using Ruby with debugger or tracer, the TypeError exception is raised:\r\n\r\n# ruby -rdebug /usr/sbin/nick\r\n/usr/lib/ruby/1.8/tracer.rb:16: Tracer is not a class (TypeError)\r\n\tfrom /usr/lib/ruby/1.8/debug.rb:10:in `require'\r\n\tfrom /usr/lib/ruby/1.8/debug.rb:10\r\n\r\nFix:\r\nThe Tracer module was renamed to SystemTap (or DTrace alternatively). If you were using Tracer.fire method in your code, please change the code to SystemTap.fire\r\n\r\nAlternatively, you can define Tracer constant yourself, using ''Tracer = SystemTap'' prior use of the .fire method, but please keep in mind that this might reintroduce this bug.\r\n\r\nResult:\r\n'ruby -rdebug' command works as expected, since the Tracer module was renamed to SystemTap, which avoids the name collision.", "cf_show_homepage": "---", "classification": "Red Hat", "is_confirmed": "True", "is_creator_accessible": "True", "cf_fixed_in": "ruby-1.8.7.374-1.el6", "creator": "---", "keywords": [ "ZStream" ], "target_release": [ "---" ], "id": "880024", "cf_release_notes": "Previously, the locking of a semtimedop semaphore operation was not fine enough with remote non-uniform memory architecture (NUMA) node accesses. As a consequence, spinlock contention occurred, which caused delays in the semop() system call and high load on the server when running numerous parallel processes accessing the same semaphore. This update improves scalability and performance of workloads with a lot of semaphore operations, especially on larger NUMA systems. This improvement has been achieved by turning the global lock for each semaphore array into a per-semaphore lock for many semaphore operations, which allows multiple simultaneous semop() operations. As a result, performance degradation no longer occurs.", "cf_show_homepage": "---", "classification": "Red Hat", "is_confirmed": "True", "is_creator_accessible": "True", "cf_fixed_in": "---", "keywords": [ "Patch" ], "target_release": [ "---" ], "id": "919545", "cf_release_notes": "Cause: \r\nAn issue in fix for Bug #734458 could cause dig tool to access already freed query when trying multiple origins during the domain name resolution.\r\n\r\nConsequence: \r\nAs a consequence the dig tool could crash with Segmentation Fault in some situations when doing a lookup. Especially when running on a host that has multiple search domains configured in the /etc/resolv.conf.\r\n\r\nFix: \r\nThe dig source has been fixed to always use a query that is still valid, when trying the next origin.\r\n\r\nResult:\r\nAs a result the dig tool now does not crash with Segmentation Fault when trying to resolve a domain name on a host that is configured with multiple search "", "severity": "high", "is_open": "True", "cf_mount_type": "---", "keywords": [ "ZStream" ], "target_release": [ "---" ], "id": "980188", "cf_release_notes": "When transferring a large amount of data over the peer-to-peer (PPP) link, a rare race condition between the throttle() and unthrottle() functions in the tty driver could be triggered. As a consequence, the tty driver became unresponsive, remaining in the throttled state, which resulted in the traffic being stalled. Also, if the PPP link was heavily loaded, another race condition in the tty driver could has been triggered. This race allowed an unsafe update of the available buffer space, which could also result in the stalled traffic. A series of patches addressing both race conditions has been applied to the tty driver; if the first race is triggered, the driver loops and forces re-evaluation of the respective test condition, which ensures uninterrupted traffic flow in the described situation. The second race is now completely avoided due to a well-placed read lock, and the update of the available buffer space proceeds correctly.", "cf_show_homepage": "---", "classification": "Red Hat", "id": "1007634", "cf_release_notes": "Cause: \r\n\r\nsnmpd, the SNMP daemon, did not cache process information when enumerating table of processes for HOST-RESOURCES-MIB::hrSWRunTable. \r\n\r\nConsequence: \r\nTwo parallel GET requests for a process in the hrSWRunTable might return inconsistent results when the process exited in the middle of processing - one GET request response contains valid information, while the second reports that the process no longer exists.\r\n\r\nFix: \r\nsnmpd caches table of running process for 5 seconds.\r\n\r\nResult: \r\nProbability of two requests returning inconsistent data is significantly lower. However, in rare cases, the cache may still expire and two GET requests may still return inconsistent data on busy systems. That's nature of SNMP protocol.", "cf_show_homepage": "---", "classification": "Red Hat", "is_confirmed": "True", "is_creator_accessible": "True", "cf_fixed_in": "", "creator": "mmatsuya@redhat.com", "page allocation failures when mlx4 is used with TransparentHugePages", "id": "1018715", "cf_release_notes": "The memory page allocation mechanism of the mlx4 driver used exclusively ''order 2'' allocations when allocating memory for incoming frames. This led to a high memory page allocation failure rate on systems with high memory fragmentation. With this update, the mlx4 driver firstly attempts to perform ''order 3'' allocations and then continues with lower order allocations up to ''order 0'' if the memory is too fragmented. As a result, performance of mlx4 cards is now significantly higher and mlx4 no longer generates memory page allocation failures when the system is under memory pressure.", "cf_show_homepage": "---", 1500 does not get set when the VM boots [6.6]", "id": "1019346", "cf_release_notes": "Previously, devices using the ixgbevf driver that were assigned to a virtual machine could not adjust their Jumbo available. They generally do this by adding up \r\n''free'' and ''cached'', which was fine ten years ago, \r\nbut is pretty much guaranteed to be wrong today.\r\n\r\nIt is wrong because Cached includes memory that is not\r\nfreeable as page cache, for example shared memory \r\nsegments, tmpfs, and ramfs, and it does not include \r\nreclaimable slab memory, which can take up a large \r\nfraction of system memory on mostly idle systems \r\nwith lots of files.\r\n\r\nCurrently, the amount of memory that is available \r\nfor a new workload, without pushing the system into swap,\r\ncan be estimated from "id": "1039534", "cf_release_notes": "A previous change removed the ZONE_RECLAIM_LOCKED flag from Linux memory management code in order to fix a NUMA node allocation problem in the memory zone reclaim logic. However, the flag removal allowed concurrent page reclaiming within one memory zone, which, under heavy system load, resulted in unwanted spin lock contention and subsequent performance problems (systems became slow or unresponsive). This update resolves this problem by preventing reclaim threads from scanning a memory zone if the zone does not satisfy scanning requirements. "ZStream" ], "target_release": [ "6.6" ], "id": "1043353", "cf_release_notes": "Previously, when hot adding memory to the system, the memory management subsystem always performed unconditional page-block scans for all memory sections being set online. The total duration of the hot add operation depends on both, the size of memory that the system already has and the size of memory that is being added. Therefore, the hot add operation took an excessive amount of time to complete if a large amount of memory was added or if the target node already had a considerable amount of memory. This update optimizes the code so that page-block scans are performed only when necessary, which greatly reduces the duration of the hot add operation.", "cf_show_homepage": "---", "classification": "", "severity": "high", "is_open": "True", "cf_mount_type": "---", "keywords": [], "target_release": [ "---" ], "id": "1046168", "cf_release_notes": "Cause: \r\nThe GFS2 file system's ''chown'' operation code had assumed that a multi-block reservation structure was always associated with an inode in memory, and it referenced that reservation structure to make quota changes. However, if the file being ''chown''ed is closed, the reservation structure may be freed from memory.\r\n\r\nConsequence: \r\nAs a result, the ''chown'' command could try to reference the reservation structure after it had been freed from memory, which resulted in a kernel panic.\r\n\r\nFix: \r\nIn the GFS2 ''chown'' code, we now gain write access to prevent any ''close'' functions from freeing the reservation structure, and we call function gfs2_rs_alloc to ensure a reservation structure exists during the operation.\r\n\r\nResult: \r\nAs a result, the reservation structure is guaranteed to exist in memory, and therefore a ''chown'' operation will not cause a kernel panic.", "cf_show_homepage": "---", "classification": "Red Hat", "is_confirmed": "True", "is_creator_accessible": "True", to accept ticket-based authentication from a client, a server was able to decrypt a ticket which was encrypted with one encryption type (for example, des-cbc-crc) as long as its keytab contained a key of a sufficiently-compatible encryption type (for example, des-cbc-md5). Due to a regression, servers could not verify the client's ticket when it did not exactly match the type of the key in the keytab file. With this update, a backported fix has been introduced to restore the aforementioned behavior. As a result, servers now verify clients' tickets when the key distribution center (KDC) issues a ticket using an encryption type for which the server does not possess an exactly-matching key.",
